Scenes of all hues, and life in every form,</br>The dark, the bright, the frozen, and the warm—</br>Urburgh, within thy ample space were seen—</br>Revel and want — and but a wall between!</br>Here wild profusion — naked famine there—</br>Here care unknown — there nothing left but care!</br>Behind where some proud mansion rear'd its head—</br>Cold winds pierc'd poverty's unfurnish'd shed:</br>Close by some glitt'ring dome, where all was bright,</br>Lay sorrow shrouded in unbroken night:</br>The very stones where want dropt down to die,</br>Shook with the equipage that rattled by;</br>Whose passing torches' ostentatious glare</br>Flash'd on the houseless victim of despair!</br>Here burst the long-loud laugh — there heav'd the groan—</br>Circl'd by anguish — pleasure flx'd her throne!</br>Show'ring on those who throng'd her golden seat,</br>For each enraptur'd sense, allurements sweet—</br>Shedding abundant on the crowded board</br>The best that art could yield, or earth afford;</br>And mingling with the wealth of every clime,</br>Whate'er amusement could give wings to time—</br>The play; the masquerade at midnight hour;</br>The concert, fraught with soul inspiring power;</br>The witching dance that bids an evening fly,</br>Swift as the convict's who is soon to die:</br>Where beauty trod with sylph-like step its maze;</br>And seem'd to grow still lovelier to the gaze:</br>The scenes where luxury and wealth combin'd</br>To banish sorrow, and enchant the mind:</br>Where sparkling chandeliers, with starry light,</br>Shone out triumphant o'er the reign of night;</br>While art and nature seem'd in contest there,</br>To deck the noble, and adorn the fair!</br>The crimson ruby, and the sapphire blue,</br>Glitter'd with every motion on the view:</br>The sunny diamond sparkled on the sight,</br>And flash'd its dazzling tints upon the night.</br>There man assumed his fair, but specious form,</br>Frigid, tho' bright, as ice-drops in the storm;</br>With elegance of manners, wit, and ease,</br>Devoting life in learning but to please</br>With smiling magic winding round the heart;</br>Blinding the thoughtless to the veil of art;</br>Whose soul, with more than iron mask conceal'd,</br>One real thought or feeling scarce reveal'd.</br>Young beauty there, (whose loveliest tint is still</br>The blush that neither comes nor goes at will,</br>But passes like the crimson cloud at eve,</br>That seems on earth a softer bloom to leave—)</br>Met the full gaze of crowds in conscious pride,</br>Nor shrank within herself, nor turn'd aside;</br>But knew the bold, repelling glance, to throw</br>On those she did not court, or would not know!</br>Cold, empty Fashion!  heartless is thy form!</br>No love can thrill it, and no friendship warm:</br>Each genuine feeling of the soul by thee</br>Is check'd, or withers in thy lethargy;</br>Wavering as meteors in the northern sky,</br>No useful beam thou shed'st on heart nor eye;</br>To scenes that might the feeling soul inspire</br>Thy vacant look denies one spark of fire:</br>Oft' have I seen thee, when the Tragic Muse</br>Essay'd her melting influence to diffuse;</br>Gaze on the anguish'd, or terrific scene,</br>With tranquil eye, and cold, unalter'd mien;</br>While other cheeks were glistening with the tear,</br>And other breasts were harrow'd up with fear:</br>Sense, genius, passion, weigh'd against thy power,</br>Nor rouse the mind, nor rule one tender hour.</br>Ah!  happier far, the scene of friends belov'd!</br>Congenial souls, long known, and often prov'd:</br>Where the full tide of feeling pours its stream,</br>And the heart gladdens in the eyes' bright beam;</br>Where all the treasur'd stores of mind are brought</br>T' enrich the feast of fancy and of thought—</br>Where tho' wit strike, mirth draws its barb away;</br>And heart-born smiles on sunny features play.</br>In such a scene how swift the moments sped!</br>The night was ended ere the charm had fled!</br>So while we gaze eve's gorgeous clouds to mark,</br>Ere we can trace their forms the heavens are dark:</br>Too soon dispersed, like those we lov'd to greet,</br>Till desolation circles round our feet;</br>And silent darkness fills the place which they</br>Peopled and brighten'd in life's younger day.</br>With them we snatch the golden hours of life—</br>The rest are passion, storm, disgust, or strife:</br>Then only shine the rays that burst between</br>The clouds of fate, to cheer life's checquer'd scene—</br>Save to the few, whose souls of wilder mood,</br>Find rapture in the depths of solitude;</br>Companion'd by each vast and thrilling thought,</br>And beings in the womb of fancy wrought;</br>Whose minds create what earth nor heaven has known,</br>Who scarce remember that they breathe alone.

In yon raz'd College, youth shall learn no more;</br>Nor doctors dully doze o'er classic lore;</br>Nor history her mould'ring page unroll;</br>Nor science raise on high th' expanding soul:</br>Nor gifted boys, to emulation fired,</br>Pant to be heard, and envied, and admired!</br>There every study that could lift the thought,</br>Before the deep and ardent mind was brought.</br>That proudly started from its brighter birth;</br>And soar'd on high, and spurn'd the bounds of earth;</br>And mark'd, in the unmeasured realms of light,</br>The planet's circle, and the comet's flight;</br>Traced suns on suns, that, 'midst the starry spheres,</br>Bestow'd on countless worlds their days and years.</br>While nature's mystic laws, unknown before,</br>Their powers reveal'd, and work'd unknown no more.</br>The mind its faculties distinguish'd, trac'd;</br>In judgment strengthen'd, and refin'd in taste.</br>There the young Poet burn'd the prize to win—</br>Bade ardent fancy's soaring flight begin;</br>And fann'd the spark of that etherial fire,</br>That beam'd a Sun for nations to admire.</br>But there no more the tutor'd soul shall rise,</br>Panting to mingle with her native skies.</br>Within those walls the monumental bust</br>Rescued the form that time had strew'd in dust;</br>Where, chisell'd on the long enduring stone,</br>The features of departed genius shone—</br>Reft — crush'd by havoc's desolating sweep—</br>Now scarce a marble marks the great who sleep;</br>And all that fate has left the living — is to weep!

No more beside the hero's trophied urn,</br>The fearless soldier feels his bosom burn;</br>Reviews the past in admiration dumb—</br>Or fondly pictures triumphs yet to come!</br>Nor near the Poet's tomb the friend of art</br>Feels inspiration kindling at his heart!</br>But ah!  how many of that fated race</br>Have left their bones where nothing marks the place;</br>Save the wild-flower that blooms above their head,</br>And drops the only tear that's o'er them shed.</br>Often, like meteors shooting thro' the night,</br>They lighten on the world — and sink from sight!</br>Too oft', like spirits of another sphere,</br>Wand'ring, they find no kindred beings here—</br>Strangers amidst the crowd they battle through—</br>Absorbed in fancy's intellectual view—</br>Scorning and scorn'd by traffic's sordid crew;</br>They breathe — they move — as if they liv'd alone;</br>Or in a wild creation of their own!</br>Scarce of the earth that bears their alien tread;</br>They live in storms, and tempests wrap their head</br>With thoughts, and hopes, and feelings, none can share—</br>They start away and perish in despair.

Here oft' I gazed, while, slowly passing by,</br>The long procession proudly caught the eye;</br>In military pomp, or civic pride,</br>And lin'd with armed hosts on either side;</br>Whether it grac'd some warrior's funeral hour,</br>Or led the monarch in his pride of power;</br>With statesmen, heroes, princes in the train</br>And graced with all wealth, valor, could obtain!</br>Such myriads throng'd, as if the nation there,</br>Came with one mind the grief or joy to share.</br>If chance some victory had plum'd the land,</br>Exulting thousands pour'd along the strand;</br>And while the cannon roll'd the news around,</br>Each seem'd to triumph in the welcome sound.</br>The joyous lamps dispell'd the shades of night;</br>Arranged like stars, with every colour bright;</br>Or Iris' bow revers'd in many-tinted light:</br>Aloft, transparent, painted trophies hung,</br>And with the conqueror's name the city rung!</br>All left their homes the midnight joy to share!</br>And with proud acclamations rent the air.</br>Alas!  they thought not then how dearly bought</br>Those triumphs, and how soon to turn to nought:</br>They did not deem that fame, so vainly won,</br>Would leave their country beggar'd and undone.</br>Alas!  the pomp no more shall traverse here!</br>And victory's last shout hath left the ear!</br>O'er all, a silent melancholy reigns,</br>That spreads (contagious) to the neighbouring plains.

Alone I pace thro' traffic's busiest seat,</br>Where thousands lately throng'd the noisy street;</br>Where beauty loiter'd many a vacant morn,</br>Seeking whatever might her charms adorn;</br>Convinced that dress imparts a higher grace</br>To each perfection of the form and face.</br>And men (tho' few) more frivolous than they,</br>Here traced the changing fashions of the day;</br>Whose dearth of mind, or idleness of thought—</br>'Twas all they could — that poor distinction sought!</br>To glitter like the gaudy butterfly—</br>To live — be seen — to flutter — and to die!</br>Here form'd for pride, or luxury, or use,</br>Was found whate'er art, nature, could produce:</br>Now the bright mantle caught th' admiring gaze—</br>Now gold and jewels shed their mingled rays:</br>And all the lures of trade, and powers of art,</br>Seem'd centred in one great capacious mart.</br>The few, by learning led, by genius fired,</br>To nobler fame, and loftier thoughts, aspired:</br>Rapt in philosophy's sublimest height,</br>Or in the Poets' wild etherial flight,</br>Eager each maze of science to explore,</br>Ambitious to increase their mental store—</br>They, 'midst the letter'd treasures, lov'd to seek</br>The volumes where the great departed speak;</br>Or living writers vied with Roman and with Greek.</br>And here the glass, defying space, was made,</br>To show the heavens in all their pride display'd;</br>Whose lengthen'd vision brings the planet nigh,</br>That shoots no ray to man's unaided eye,</br>Lost with its moons amidst the boundless sky—</br>Nor less amazing, that which brings to light</br>Myriads of forms, impalpable to sight;</br>But which, beneath the optic power, appear</br>An almost hidden world of beings here;</br>Active with life as those that tread the plain—</br>Perchance as sensible of joy or pain!</br>Perfect in parts, a countless, varied race;</br>With scarce a portion of the realm of space!</br>Thus shown, the insect we might crush unseen,</br>A bulk gigantic wears, and monster's mien!</br>And here th' electric tube reveal'd to sight</br>The mystic fluid of supernal might:</br>Whose dread explosion rends the echoing air,</br>As if unearthly beings battled there;</br>While midnight lightning frights the timid soul;</br>And lengthen'd peals of thunder shake the pole!</br>The painted globe display'd its varied book,</br>For man to look on, as a God might look—</br>Who sees the earth an atom whirling round—</br>A speck amidst the infinite profound!</br>Yet, on its narrow space, what passions burn,</br>Blight its fair face, and man to demon turn.</br>Upon some plain he casts his craving eye—</br>There slays his kind — and then lies down to die!</br>Whate'er could vigour to his mind impart,</br>Or prove the depth of thought, the powers of art;</br>All that could splendour on his days bestow—</br>Here perfect shone — the noon of life below.

Scarce can I trace where once the Tavern stood,</br>Where men of learning met in cheerful mood;</br>Where oft', when twilight robed the west in gray,</br>They came to close in joy a studious day:</br>Then various questions bred debates profound,</br>Broken as wine or wit by turns went round!</br>There Philo boasted how he knew the men</br>Who ruled the realm — what they design'd, and when—</br>What letter last he penn'd to save the state—</br>What satire levell'd at the guilty great!</br>The Poet there reveal'd his patron's name,</br>His fancied guide to fortune and to fame!</br>To doubtful friends his sanguine hopes display'd;</br>And had been happy — had his debts been paid.</br>The Critic told — as much as critics do—</br>What pages then were passing in review:</br>What wings were clipt, to check the further fright</br>Of some young bard, who aim'd to reach the height</br>Parnassus tempting shows — what work struck dead,</br>Left harmless curses on his nameless head.</br>The Doctor there forgot his numerous slain,</br>Laugh'd o'er the glass, and "was himself again"!</br>And men of letters show'd some rare unique,</br>Purchas'd, perchance, where none such gem would seek.</br>Lov'd scene of converse!  seat of mental glee!</br>Now lost for ever both to them and me!</br>Where such a circle can I hope to find?</br>Such letter'd friendship, or such feast of mind?</br>Each intellectual joy has taken flight,</br>And learning finds another Gothic night:</br>Refinement backward treads her steps again,</br>And man has toil'd a thousand years in vain!</br>So when an earthquake shakes a polish'd realm,</br>And the ground opens, cities, plains, to whelm;</br>A wild and barren desert meets the day;</br>Whence all the pride of art has sunk away.

Near where yon obelisk its point displays,</br>A Market echo'd on accustom'd days;</br>Whose numerous lights, upon the evening air,</br>Shed far around a red and wavering glare:</br>Where, jostling through the crowd, and viewing all,</br>The laborer urg'd his way from stall to stall.</br>There did the sun-burnt gardener weekly bring</br>The fruits of autumn, or the flowers of spring;</br>And many a farmer thither brought his store,</br>Who having sold it, car'd for nothing more.</br>There half the neighbouring fields their treasures pour'd;</br>And plenty seem'd to spread the general board;</br>Earth, ocean, air, their various tribes supplied—</br>For man's repast, fish, fowl, and flock had died!</br>Who there might gaze, would never dream of dearth;</br>It seem'd the very magazine of earth!</br>While rattling bustle and tumultuous noise,</br>Echoed from wheels and horses, men and boys;</br>Superior far, though grating to the ear,</br>Than the dead silence now prevailing here.

Fall'n — desert City!  splendid was thy state!</br>Ages had o'er thee roll'd to make thee great!</br>Tempest and toil thy people struggled through,</br>To see thee rise in grandeur to the view!</br>How slowly did thy temple pierce the day!</br>How gradually thy streets their length display:</br>Year after year beheld them stretch along;</br>And peopled by a still increasing throng—</br>With ceaseless step they pierc'd the fields around,</br>Till mansions prest the lately cultur'd ground;</br>And roof and steeple glitter'd in the sky,</br>Where recent woods had waved their boughs on high!</br>Nought stopt thy progress!  forest — river — hill—</br>Beheld thee pass their feeble barriers still—</br>O'er leafless leagues one mass of buildings spread;</br>Till every trace of rural life had fled!</br>Till e'en the villages that round thee bloom'd,</br>At last within thy giant grasp were tomb'd.</br>It seem'd as if mankind had gather'd there,</br>One general fate of good or ill to share:</br>The foot that tried to trace thy ample round,</br>Wearied ere half thy devious course was found.</br>The wond'ring traveller hail'd thy noontide fame;</br>And the whole world resounded with thy name.</br>But ah!  how quickly in destruction strew'd,</br>When fled thy people, scatter'd and subdued!</br>Thus the slow oak expands in pride below—</br>But struck by lightning, withers at a blow!</br>As scenes of past prosperity appear,</br>Who now could view thee and refuse the tear?</br>'Midst the drear shadows of this wreck I trace</br>The banish'd pleasures of each well known place—</br>Till darker grow the ruins on mine eye,</br>And grief compels the unavailing sigh.

Pass we this gate, beneath the colonnade;</br>The pillars in the square within display'd,</br>Enclose the area of the late Exchange;</br>Where captains, merchants, mingled to arrange</br>The world's vast trade, as though all nations there,</br>Came its enriching intercourse to share.</br>Men from all climes, as if by one consent,</br>Met in one throng, inspir'd by one intent;</br>From Europe's nearest and remotest shore—</br>And Western Islands where tornadoes roar—</br>From Asia's groves, once man's fair seat of prime;</br>And Afric, hindmost in the march of time—</br>From wide Columbia, bursting into power,</br>Where freedom fled in her despairing hour;</br>When, of each famed and cherish'd spot bereft,</br>She sought the sole asylum fate had left;</br>Till renovating time should call her back,</br>To bless once more each early favor'd track.</br>Of all the world this spot might seem the heart;</br>That urged the vital stream to every part:</br>Whence each to others sent what each could spare,</br>Till nature's bounty all contrived to share!</br>The rich abundance of the fruitful field—</br>What surplus stores the hand of toil could yield—</br>Here found a ready mart, a transfer sure,</br>To bless the wealthy, and enrich the poor.</br>Here rival nations, spite of hate or pride,</br>Seem'd in one social brotherhood allied;</br>As if war, interest, ne'er had spread a cloud,</br>The sunshine of so fair a scene to shroud.

And near that busy spot the Bank arose;</br>The nation's pride — the envy of her foes!</br>Whence, as from some exhaustless mine of gold,</br>The stream of wealth o'er all the country roll'd;</br>And distant realms, and hostile too, had share</br>In riches' magic influence reigning there:</br>As there had work'd some deep pervading spell,</br>That drew from every clime its stores to swell;</br>And bade all earth in confidence repose</br>On honor that was sacred e'en to foes.</br>And thence the vital stream return'd to all,</br>Like welcome showers on burning fields that fall;</br>Or some unfailing spring that bursts to light,</br>And onward rolls increasing to the sight:</br>Till o'er the land the fruitful river pours,</br>And loads with riches its exulting shores;</br>Then mingles with the sea, and spreads around,</br>Wherever ocean rolls, or man is found.</br>What joyous crowds each day collected there,</br>The produce of their treasur'd hoards to share!</br>How many thousands drew from thence th' increase</br>That blest their days with ease, their nights with peace!</br>The spring of commerce, and the heart of trade,</br>It bade its influence all the land pervade:</br>And if the sudden cry of war arose—</br>It arm'd the hosts that flew to meet their foes;</br>And launch'd the fleets that swept the vanquish'd main,</br>The nation's glory foremost to maintain!</br>The bulwark of the land — the soul of all—</br>Its honour stood unquestion'd in its fall!</br>And when it fell, in hostile ruin hurl'd—</br>It seem'd as if an earthquake shook the world!</br>And distant cities started from their sleep;</br>And nations woke to hear the tale and weep;</br>And lamentations rose from every shore,</br>That one so rich — so mighty — was no more!

Ill-fated land!  to ruin doom'd a prey!</br>Where wars perpetual sweep mankind away!</br>Or whence the riches of the nation fly,</br>That distant lands may mourn, and armies die.</br>In vain thy fields with rip'ning treasures bloom—</br>Amidst their wealth want oft' but finds a tomb!</br>In vain thy merchants and thy peasants toil,</br>While war exhausts thee, or while armies spoil!</br>False is the smile that decks thy laborer's cheek—</br>And ill conceals the dread he fears to speak!</br>And still the mask of safety covers all—</br>Nor drops — but at the nation's final fall.</br>Even when subjugation hovers nigh,</br>The gilded surface cheats the patriot eye:</br>And though each ruler knows his country's state—</br>And every peasant trembles for her fate—</br>Still will th' infatuate statesmen of the land,</br>Provoke the vengeance of a hostile hand;</br>Or goad her, till impatient of the chain,</br>She rise to burst the galling links in twain.</br>In such a realm — O!  what must man endure!</br>No joy is certain, and no life secure.

From such a land — the seat of strife and woe;</br>In search of happier climes, the people go.</br>But much, and long — (though scarce in hope,) they bear;</br>Ere from their father's graves their steps they tear—</br>Ere from the seat of youth's past joys they fly,</br>Upon some foreign, friendless shore, to die!</br>A thousand strong attachments rise around,</br>To chain their footsteps to that hallow'd ground:</br>Still dear to sight their childhood scenes appear;</br>And in the parting moment-doubly dear!</br>The barren heath that infant footsteps prest,</br>May breathe enchantment round the manly breast:</br>The stream where boyhood plunged his limbs to lave,</br>In age's eye seems an unalter'd wave—</br>The trees — the rocks — that rise in native air;</br>This mystic — nameless sense — appear to share!</br>The links of friendship — kindred's heartstring ties—</br>That bind the spirit to its native skies—</br>And all these feelings tongue can scarce define,</br>Home's magic charms around the soul entwine—</br>These may be felt, but scarcely can be told;</br>Nor oft are sever'd till the breast is cold.</br>Yet fate, despite of all these bonds, may tear</br>The soul away; wrongs, sorrows, none can bear,</br>May urge the man some kinder spot to find,</br>Who leaves his fondest feelings still behind.</br>But oh!  what wrongs, what sorrows must they be,</br>To launch him thus on fortune's treacherous sea;</br>When habits, flx'd like instinct in the soul,</br>Have power each thought and feeling to controul—</br>Commencing life anew, when cares should cease;</br>And, labor rest upon the lap of peace;</br>Where scarce a hope can rise, ere life must close,</br>To see the dawn of pleasure, or repose.</br>They whose misrule compels such hearts to roam,</br>Should live to feel how keen the loss of home;</br>To sigh their last beneath some distant skies,</br>And sink, without a friend to close their eyes.</br>Yes!  spite of all these spells of soul, they flee—</br>'Tis their sole hope — some land more just to see!</br>Where peace may still her calm assurance spread,</br>And equal laws their guarding influence shed:</br>Where night in safe repose may steal away,</br>Contentment bless, and hope illume the day:</br>Where dying they may trust their sons will see</br>Life growing — bright'ning in prosperity;</br>And where at least the fruits of toil will yield</br>Their boon to him who cultivates the field.</br>The merchant takes his wealth to climes like these,</br>There to ensure tranquillity and ease;</br>The swain seeks ground secure from hostile tread,</br>Content to find some peace-protected shed;</br>Blest that his toil may not be spent in vain</br>For hearts that spurn him — hands that forge his chain.</br>Urg'd by distress, the sons of art retire,</br>Where hope may cheer them, and success inspire;</br>They quit a land with pomp, not freedom, graced;</br>A noble desert, and a splendid waste!</br>Far — far they urge their distant course away,</br>Through wat'ry wastes to realms of brighter day:</br>A rising nation hails them to her shore,</br>And bids the welcome wand'rers fear no more!</br>Such emigrations feed a new-born state,</br>But urge the realm they quit to swifter fate;</br>The heart's best blood forsakes the fated land;</br>Its absent treasures aid that rival's hand:</br>Th' unlessen'd burthens those they leave must bear,</br>Until taxation battles with despair!</br>The handicraftsmen there their arts pursue,</br>And prove a source of power, and riches too.</br>Thus rolls the ceaseless change from shore to shore—</br>Thus nations rise — thus fall to rise no more!</br>The seat of empire moves from clime to clime,</br>Nor e'er prevails against the power of time.</br>So here the ocean gains upon the land—</br>And there, receding, leaves a blooming strand;</br>Till over spire and turret rolls the wave,</br>Or cities rise upon the coral cave!</br>Urburgh o'er every realm her flag unfurl'd;</br>Herself an island — yet she awed the world!</br>When she arose, and bared her mighty arm</br>For battle — nations trembled with alarm—</br>Her look was lightning — and a thunder peal</br>Her threat; that made the hostile shores to reel.</br>Her giant grasp embraced from pole to pole;</br>And east and west own'd her supreme controul:</br>Men of all tongues, all climes, confess'd her reign,</br>Queen of the isles, and mistress of the main.</br>But, like a brilliant star that bursts to sight,</br>Her empire spread in wreck, and sank in night.</br>Yet still — her name — her glory, ne'er can die,</br>While earth shall track her orbit through the sky.</br>'Tis true, the greatest states decline and fall;</br>But to their rulers we impute it all.</br>Look back!  and trace, in the historic scene,</br>What Carthage, Rome, and more as proud have been—</br>Then say what strew'd their honors in the dust,</br>But wasting wars, and governments unjust!</br>It is not that th' exhausted earth denies</br>The seed to ripen — 'tis not that the skies</br>Refuse to bless her with the timely shower;</br>Nor is it that the sun withholds his power—</br>The ground is fertile still; the seasons roll;</br>And summer, winter, pass o'er either pole:</br>The morn yet rises on his golden wing,</br>And evening falls her balmy dews to fling—</br>Still nature pours her wealth o'er hill and plain;</br>'Tis man alone that makes her bloom in vain.

Yes — life has evils!  earth is charged with woe!</br>Unclouded fortune ne'er was found below!</br>Here warring passions strew the wreck of strife—</br>There nature rends with pain the strings of life!</br>The flowery prospects of the youthful eye</br>A darken'd scene in manhood's vigour die;</br>And manhood's hopes — since hope can scarce be lost—</br>Set in the lasting chill of age's frost!</br>Oft' by Volcanoes realms in wreck are hurl'd:</br>A sacrifice, perchance, to save a world—</br>Yet Nature's general laws are more than kind;</br>Man is the greatest foe that man can find.</br>If Nature rend the earth — she heals the wound!</br>To hide the ruin — spreads profusion round!</br>Man leaves the victim who has met his blow,</br>Till the last drop, unstaunch'd, unwept, shall flow!</br>Whether she smite with fire, or flood, or air,</br>Nature but seldom leaves complete despair;</br>But the dark ruin of despotic sway</br>Blasts earth and man, and sweeps his hopes away.</br>Eats, like the Mole, the germ of future wealth;</br>And poisons all the springs of life and health:</br>Steals the sole joy the sinking poor have left;</br>Whose last is gone when liberty is reft.</br>Thou, Urburgh!  of this curse hadst more than share—</br>A century saw thee verging to despair!</br>Slowly but sure the secret poison work'd—</br>Deep in thy heart its deadly influence lurk'd—</br>Long years of wasteful war thy vitals wore;</br>And pour'd thy gold on many a hostile shore;</br>Till burthens destin'd for a race unborn,</br>Made thee of earth the beacon and the scorn.</br>Thou who unharm'd — untouch'd — might'st still have stood—</br>To aid the cause of despots shed thy blood!</br>Who having triumph'd, leagu'd to bind in chains</br>The cheated world, and robb'd thee for thy pains.</br>Thy rulers, selfish, cruel, and unjust,</br>Devour'd thy wealth, and strew'd thy rights in dust:</br>Too often ranged against the public weal,</br>With scarcely souls to judge, or hearts to feel;</br>Clinging to power, despite of public hate;</br>Urging with desperate acts the nation's fate—</br>Blind to the mental progress of mankind;</br>Themselves the hindmost in the march of mind;</br>In them nor art nor science found a friend,</br>One cheering smile, one aiding hand to lend;</br>In their despite improvements spread along,</br>Till mightiest spirits started from the throng;</br>And bay'd them to their teeth, and dar'd their power;</br>And shook the throne itself in that wild hour!</br>Once, from all climes, men flew to thee for aid—</br>Then thy rich left thee, lonely and betray'd!</br>Thy noblest spirits sought some happier realm,</br>Ere all their hopes thy hast'ning fate should whelm;</br>Or too indignant to endure the chain,</br>They saw thee, heaving, pant to burst in vain.</br>Each class sank slowly in the social scale;</br>Th' industrious found their toil of no avail;</br>And famine, stealing to the laborer's cot,</br>Breathed life's last curse on his unhappy lot.</br>When want in threat'ning murmurs found a vent—</br>Then — did the tyrants tremble and relent?</br>No!  despots for themselves alone can feel—</br>They heard the prayer — they answer'd with the steel!</br>They first embrued the sword in native blood</br>That pour'd in after times a hideous flood:</br>That sword, they deem'd, would still a nation's cries</br>And silence wrongs that thunder'd to the skies.</br>Weak — shallow hope!  when men have reach'd the worst,</br>Their wrath explodes in one volcanic burst!</br>'Tis not for him to fear the chance of strife,</br>Who finds no blessing left to sweeten life—</br>Assured no change — whatever change may be—</br>Can see him deeper sunk in misery.</br>And who, with mortal feelings, fails to chuse</br>The chance to win, with nothing left to lose?</br>On whom, should death alight, it does but shed</br>The long repose that stills the aching head.</br>'Twas then, when civil strife the land assail'd,</br>The watchful foe attack'd her and prevail'd:</br>'Twas then the ruin, such as now I see,</br>Fell on my hapless country, and on me.

Yes!  I remember well that fatal day</br>When noble Urburgh fell, the despots' prey:</br>The previous night, when hostile armies closed</br>Around her barriers, not an eye reposed;</br>Thousands were listening to the distant drum,</br>To judge how nigh the gathering foe was come:</br>The cannons' bursting sound, that cleav'd the air,</br>Was follow'd by the blankness of despair!</br>At intervals some shooting rocket rose,</br>A signal to direct the march of foes.</br>The mansions pour'd their inmates on the street,</br>Where mingling strangers seem'd like friends to meet;</br>At every turn some crowd consulting stood,</br>Dreading the coming morn would rise in blood.</br>And there was hurrying, rushing to and fro</br>Of man and horse — a people whelm'd in woe!</br>And men were shouting for their friends; and cries</br>Of women trembled in the echoing skies!</br>The high — the low — were blended in one throng,</br>That like a stormy river roll'd along;</br>All ranks abroad, as by one impulse, flock'd,</br>Leaving their dwellings darken'd and unlock'd;</br>Save where a light through some lone casement beam'd,</br>That like a meteor o'er the tempest gleam'd;</br>Whose inmates hurried through the sleepless night</br>The preparation for the morrow's flight.</br>The time had been — and here — when such an hour</br>Had found those thousands sunk in slumber's power—</br>Breathing unconscious life, or dreaming bliss—</br>But sleep could never reign o'er scene like this;</br>Where shouts and curses — terror and despair—</br>Roll'd all their mingled sounds along the air.</br>Once he who through the streets, at midnight, past,</br>Might deem himself of all mankind the last;</br>So peaceful, solitary, still and dead—</br>As all who throng'd them yesterday were fled—</br>Now — 'twas but like a day bereft of light;</br>A sunless noon of tempest and affright!

Thousands departed ere the morning rose,</br>That saw the City traversed by her foes:</br>'Twas the last day that shone upon her fame—</br>The evening left her nothing but a name—</br>That now resounds a warning word to all,</br>Of the sure causes of a nation's fall.</br>Who lived of her enslavers, fled the first—</br>The hopeless — reckless — stay'd to brave the worst!</br>In sullen hate upon the foe they gazed;</br>And cursed the hostile flag that triumph raised;</br>Borne by the very hands that oft' before</br>Had lost the trophies Urburgh proudly wore.</br>In endless columns they advanc'd along,</br>Safe in her weakness, and in numbers strong;</br>Like the fierce torrent that the mountain pours,</br>Tearing the ravaged vales through which it roars.</br>The heavy tread of many thousand feet,</br>Shaking the ground, past on from street to street;</br>The tramp of steed follow'd the rumbling gun,</br>And noon was glowing ere their march was done—</br>The drums that peal'd their thunder on the air,</br>Roll'd the last echoes of a land's despair;</br>And the shrill trumpet's loud and piercing breath,</br>Burst on the fallen like the blast of death!</br>Yes — there were bitter feelings none could speak—</br>And proud men look'd the wrath they could not wreak—</br>And they whose hopes had with their country's grown</br>Long'd for a look might turn that host to stone!</br>The pride of manhood struggled with despair;</br>And hands were clench'd as if a sword were there;</br>And the last feeling of the soul was shame,</br>That thus should set their country's star of fame.

Collected in one Square, a patriot band,</br>Held life's last struggle for their native land;</br>Who rather than behold her final woe,</br>Would fight to save, or fall amidst the foe.</br>How fierce — how fatal — in that spot, the strife!</br>None would surrender — though the boon was life!</br>From every street that form'd an entrance there,</br>The foe advanced to wedge them in despair:</br>From every opening rending thunders pour'd,</br>That, echoing round, in long loud vollies roar'd:</br>Through living lines of men the bolts were hurl'd,</br>Which, as they heard them, dash'd them from the world.</br>That post they held ev'n while they shed their blood</br>Slaughter'd and crush'd in masses as they stood:</br>The dead and mangled that around them lay,</br>A rampart seem'd to keep the foe at bay;</br>Where muskets rested on some friend's cold form,</br>Prolong'd the fierce, but unavailing storm.</br>The iron shower in fatal fury flew—</br>The strife of wrath more wild and deadly grew;</br>As the long rumbling tempest pours at last</br>Its deepest rage in one collected blast!</br>Oft' fell some shatter'd building's loosen'd wall,</br>That whelm'd the dead and living in its fall—</br>Oft' the foe rush'd into the charnel square—</br>As oft' retiring, left their bravest there!</br>Still the last wreck of that determin'd band</br>Braced every nerve to perish hand to hand!</br>Then close they came, and vengeance had her fill,</br>And life's last energies were rous'd to kill:</br>And the hot breath was felt, (so near they drew—)</br>As if the purple blast of poison blew.</br>There scarce was room to whirl the sword around,</br>That rose to cleave its victim to the ground:</br>While grappling, even in the pangs of death,</br>They look'd the curse that fell with life's last breath.</br>From house to house they fought — from room to room,</br>And in those lordly mansions met their doom:</br>Doors shatter'd — stain'd with blood — remain'd to tell</br>The tale of those who bravely fought and fell:</br>And heroes dropp'd, life's crimson stream to pour</br>Upon the richly decorated floor;</br>And shouts and tumults in those chambers rung,</br>Where night her veil o'er silent couches flung:</br>Where once the concert pour'd its witching strain,</br>Echoed the clash of swords, the groans of pain!</br>Floors, where the joyous dance its mazes spread,</br>Shook with the struggling warriors' heavy tread:</br>Where elegance in golden luxury dwelt—</br>Where every bliss of polish'd life was felt—</br>The rage of slaughter breathed — the blows of death were dealt!</br>So oft' some sweetly smiling, favor'd scene,</br>Adorn'd with flowers, and ever cloth'd in green;</br>Where ages past had smoothly roll'd away;</br>Nor brought one freezing, burning, stormy day—</br>Beholds at last a sudden tempest driven,</br>Gather'd and borne upon the winds of heaven;</br>That bursts with desolating force around,</br>And strews with wreck the lately smiling ground.

The day's last streak of light dissolved away;</br>The strife was done — for none were left to slay!</br>Of all that desperate, devoted band,</br>Not one remain'd to move a hostile hand.</br>Their patriot fire was quench'd — their duty o'er—</br>The spark extinct that nothing can restore!</br>And they were stretch'd upon the silent bier;</br>The last — sole resting place, that waits us here.</br>Though late so anxious — then it wrung them not</br>Though war their nation from the earth should blot—</br>They died attempting to maintain her blest,</br>Nor foe nor tyrant more could mar their rest.</br>Their grave — that ground on which their faith they prov'd,</br>Was still their portion in the land they lov'd.

But how felt they — whose lot had there been cast</br>In peace and hope — now hope was almost past!</br>Who saw in horror, stupor, or despair,</br>The storm of war let loose in fury there!</br>There — where their mornings broke in tranquil light;</br>And fear ne'er stole upon the stilly night:</br>Who view'd their homes, the prey of lawless bands;</br>Their mansions kindled by enfuriate hands,</br>Their own and children's heritage, destroy'd;</br>Their native scenes a wreck'd and blacken'd void!</br>That night — who saw it, and has being yet,</br>Its blasting horrors never can forget!</br>The plund'ring foe swept the vast city round,</br>And made a spoil of all the wealth they found:</br>And many a cry, from victims in their power,</br>Pierc'd through the roar of that tumultuous hour!</br>But some, who straggled from their host too far,</br>Flash'd their last glance upon the midnight star;</br>Vengeance assail'd them where was no retreat,</br>And patriot weapons slew them in the street;</br>So vast the circuit of the city spread,</br>Thousands might fall, and pile the heap of dead;</br>Nor distant friends the shout of tumult hear;</br>Nor scarce the cannon's signal reach the ear:</br>In suburbs far remote, resistance rose;</br>And bath'd their pavements in the blood of foes.</br>One man I knew — and he was desperate then—</br>In happier times the best of patriot men;</br>Alone his house he paced, resolved to die,</br>If o'er his threshold past an enemy:</br>The warlike powder lay in heaps below;</br>And torch, hand, heart — were ready for the blow!</br>Determin'd with one blast to dash away</br>Himself, and them, ere he would fall their prey!</br>The foe beheld — and shudder'd at the sight,</br>And left him to his desolated right.</br>Some silent, reckless, in their chambers sate;</br>Nor sought, nor shunn'd, nor scarcely fear'd their fate.</br>Gaz'd on the flame's red glow, that spread on high;</br>And listen'd to the shouts that rent the sky;</br>With all that apathy the wretch may know,</br>Who counts the number of his hours below;</br>While those who still thought being worth their care,</br>Fled from the wreck in terror and despair;</br>Though strong affections, that still clung behind,</br>With keenest anguish wrung the tortur'd mind.</br>Forc'd from their homes, from scenes so long ador'd,</br>From every avenue their numbers pour'd;</br>The man of wealth, and luxury, and pride,</br>Disdain'd not, in the flight, the beggar's side;</br>Th' industrious artizan, in deep despair,</br>Lost all the savings of a life of care;</br>His wife, in fear and sorrow, grasp'd his arm;</br>Her sole defence against impending harm:</br>In love's strong clasp his trembling child he prest,</br>And felt its beating heart against his breast;</br>More dearly priz'd, as danger drew more nigh,</br>Determin'd to preserve it, or to die!</br>The tradesman fled his venerated home;</br>A wand'rer in the eve of life to roam:</br>And females, madden'd by the worst of fears,</br>Their hearts in anguish, and their eyes in tears;</br>Nurtur'd in scenes of elegance and ease;</br>Grac'd by each polish'd art, and form'd to please—</br>Then did their delicate and lovely forms</br>Endure, unhous'd, the rudely beating storms.</br>Youths with fond care their feeble parents led;</br>And dried with filial love the tears they shed:</br>Some silent droop'd, as in life's last despair—</br>Others with fruitless cries assail'd the air.</br>Still, as with heavy heart the gate they past,</br>One feeling bade them turn and look their last!</br>Weeping the ruin that they could not stem,</br>They fled what had been all the world to them:</br>Danger behind them, and distress before;</br>E'en hope portray'd not one bright scene in store.</br>And O!  if there be aught the mind can wring;</br>Or plant in life's last days a cureless sting;</br>'Tis to be doom'd in age from home to part,</br>And force to unknown scenes a wither'd heart—</br>To feel affections, habits, wrench'd away—</br>And yet find all these griefs too weak to slay;</br>Backward to turn in vain the longing eye,</br>Yet farther stray beneath an alien sky;</br>To wake, when life hath lost its wish to range,</br>To new disquiets and a hopeless change.

Accursed War!  thou foe of ev'ry joy!</br>Thou dost but move creation to destroy!</br>The plains are blacken'd by thy fiery path;</br>And blooming valleys wither in thy wrath:</br>There blazing cities turn th' horizon red—</br>And here the ashes of a village spread!</br>Shedding on man and earth thy pois'nous breath,</br>Thy track is mark'd by one long line of death.</br>By thee the emerald sea is stain'd with blood,</br>That spreads its crimson cloud along the flood:</br>Fierce as the loudest thunder bursts thy roar—</br>Thy worst of lightnings cleave the fated shore!</br>From thee earth's best and bravest meet their doom;</br>And nations form one universal tomb:</br>The mangled lie upon the ground to groan—</br>The dying writhe, and pour th' unheeded moan;</br>While distant friendship breathes the fruitless prayer</br>For him who bleeds to death, unaided there.</br>Man, and his hopes, together pass from day;</br>While anguish rends the thread of life away;</br>Or driv'n a wand'rer from his earliest home,</br>But lives an outcast o'er the world to roam.</br>What desolation is around thee seen!</br>What hopeless wreck where'er thy rout hath been!</br>A needful evil, if indeed thou art,</br>They who provoke thee, least endure thy smart!</br>The tears of orphans in thy footsteps flow;</br>Thy tread but echoes to the widow's woe;</br>Science before thy swift destruction flies;</br>And art in ruin sinks, and commerce dies:</br>The muses fly to some calm, peaceful shore;</br>And agriculture tills the ground no more:</br>The worst of passions in thy train appear;</br>And ghastly famine closes up the rear.</br>Forcing man back to barbarous days again,</br>His path of light is darken'd by thy reign:</br>The works of genius, and of time, expire;</br>Life's charms are lost, and joy and hope retire.</br>Thus when Vesuvius pours her fires around,</br>And sudden desolation whelms the ground;</br>Flames sweep away the valley's lovely bloom,</br>And sink the fruits of labor to the tomb.

Urburgh!  thou seat of glory, and of bliss—</br>Could nothing save thee from a doom like this!</br>Alas!  and could not riches — valor — all</br>That renders nations safe, prevent thy fall!</br>What — when thy sword, that scarce was drawn in vain,</br>Was winning empire on some distant plain—</br>When over far-off seas thy thunders flash'd;</br>And hostile fleets beneath their surges dash'd—</br>While half the world still named thee with alarm—</br>Was fate to wither thy undaunted arm;</br>And strike thee down, 'ere time had stol'n thy power;</br>And shed this darkness on thy noontide hour!</br>So have I seen, in manhood's strength and bloom,</br>Death's victim hurried to a sudden tomb.</br>But why in anguish should I linger here,</br>Where every object but provokes a tear?</br>O'erwhelming sorrow bids me shun the view,</br>Thou early lov'd — my native spot — adieu!</br>But still, whatever realm salutes mine eyes,</br>Thy cherish'd beauties will in memory rise;</br>The brightest scenes that earth to me can show,</br>Compared with thee, will prove a waste of woe;</br>Along whatever clime my feet may rove,</br>Thou still wilt live the idol of my love:</br>Long as I breathe — however far I stray—</br>My heart is here, nor will be torn away;</br>To thee my fondness must be ever true;</br>My home — my hope — my native scene, adieu!</br>
